data.title: San Francisco Film Festival
data.text:
Comments: Accepted the David O. Selznick Memorial Silver Laurel Award on the behalf of Pier Paolo Pasolini for the film The Gospel According to Saint Matthew.

1966

Comments: Attended tribute in his honor, Opening Night, October 10: clips program at Palace of Fine Arts, followed by black-tie dinner at the St. Francis Hotel. The following afternoon there was another film clips program, this one with Q&A.

1979

Comments: President of the Academy and apart of the Hollywood Advisory Comittee for the festival. Honored in 1966 Craft of Cinema retrospective.

1963

1964

1966

Comments: Accepted the Samuel Goldwyn Award for Funny Girl with producer Ray Stark, which was given out before the screening of The Touchables.

1968

Comments: Film Industry Advisor for the Festival Board 1965. Appeared at Leo McCarey retrospective in 1965 (McCarey was ill and didn\'t attend), at which Going My Way was screened. Introduced Gene Kelly at Opening Night in 1968.

1965, Going My Way, Actor

1968

Comments: Attended the gala premiere of her film Rich and Famous the day before Opening Night at the 1981 festival. Attended Opening Night in 1990 with husband Louis Malle, director of May Fools.

1981, Rich and Famous, Actor

1990

Comments: Subject of a tribute in 1986. Received Piper-Heidsieck Award in 1993. Participated in panel entitled Picturing Development in conjunction with appearance as Executive Producer of Bamako in 2007. Frequent Festival attendee.

1986

1993, To Sleep with Anger, Actor

2007, Bamako, Executive Producer/Actor

Comments: Closing night film in 1984; other Talking Heads members also attended. Appeared at the 1993 Festival to present clips program of Cuban music called Eurrragh! All four Heads in person for 1999 rerelease.

1984, Stop Making Sense, Film Subject

1993

1999, Stop Making Sense, Film Subject

Comments: Participated in seminar on Eastern European cinema in 1993. Appeared when WR: Mysteries of the Organism was chosen for Indelible Images by Wayne Wang in 1998.

1998, WR: Mysteries of the Organism, Director

1993, Gorilla Bathes at Noon, Director

1971, WR: Mysteries of the Organism, Director

Comments: Dmytryk grew up in San Francisco, the son of Ukrainian immigrants. Hollywood filmmaker served on Golden Gate jury in 1959. He returned in 1960 to speak on a panel entitled \"The Role of Film in International Cultural Relations.\"

1959

1960

Comments: Director of Come and See (SFIFF 1985) and head of the Filmmakers’ Union accepted the Mel Novikoff Award for the Soviet Filmmakers’ Union.

1989

Comments: Golden Door was the Opening Night film of the 50th San Francisco International Film Festival. Crialese attended the Castro Theatre screening April 26, 2007 and participated in a Q&A session after the film.

1998, Once We Were Strangers, Director

2003, Respiro, Director

2007, Golden Door, Director

Comments: Czechlosovakian in attendance with Martin Fric; Accepted the David O. Selznick Memorial Silver Laurel Award on the behalf of Jan Kadar and Elmar Klos for the film The Shop on Main Street.

1966, Long Live the Republic, Producer

Comments: Attended Opening Night in 1968. Festival guest in 1971. Subject of a Craft of Cinema tribute in 1972; 1975 recipient of the St. Francis of Assisi Award presented by Mayor Joseph Alioto; award was presented at the Opening Night Party at the Hyatt Regency. Attended screening of Akira Kurosawa’s Kagemusha in 1980. Chose Black God, White Devil for Indelible Images in 1997.

1968

1971

1972, The Rain People, Director

1975

1980

1981

1995, My Family, Producer

1997

2001

Comments: Honored in the 1966 Craft of Cinema retrospective. Attended the screening of his film Rich and Famous the day before Opening Night of the Festival in 1981.

1966, David Copperfield, Director

1981, Rich and Famous, Director

Comments: Attended 1979 Opening Night tribute to Alec Guinness. Attended screening of Kagemusha in 1980, which he helped to finance. Attended reception for Akira Kurosawa in 1986. Received one-time only Irving M. Levin Award in honor of the Festival\'s founder in 2007. Also attended world premiere of Fog City Mavericks and participated in post-screening Q&A session at the Castro Theatre, April 29, 2007.

1979

1980, Kagemusha, Producer

1986

2007, Fog City Mavericks, Documentary Subject

Comments: U.S. Information Agency representative and son of the famous director in attendance in 1963. Presented the David O. Selznick Award for best actor at the 9th Annual San Francisco International Film Society.

1963

1985, George Stevens: A Filmmaker’s Journey, Director

Comments: President of MPAA made a \"major address\" at a luncheon at the Fairmont Hotel on October 29 during the Festival.

1966

Comments: He was an honored guest and speaker at Opening Night during the 1967 festival. The same year the film he produced, The London Nobody Knows, was shown.

1967, The London Nobody Knows, Producer

Comments: Part of 11-hour tribute, longest in Festival history to that time. Four features, chosen by Moreau, were shown. Moreau appeared at screening.

1974, The Lovers, Actor

1974, Jules and Jim, Actor

1974, Bay of Angels, Actor

1974, Diary of a Chambermaid, Actor

1976, Lumiere, Director, Actor

Comments: Beloved Infidel was the first Hollywood entry to the SFIFF. Wald was the producer of San Francisco-set films Dark Passage and Kiss Them for Me.

1959, Beloved Infidel, Producer

Comments: Hosted the awards show for the best of the television section of the Festival in 1967.

1967

Comments: Attended the 1977 Festival with the subjects of Who Are the Debolts and How Did They get Nineteen Kids?

1967, Funnyman, Director

1968, Riverrun, Director

1975, The Music School, Director

1977, Who Are the DeBolts? (And Where Did They Get 19 Kids?), Director

1985, Fast Forward, Director

Comments: Introduced Yellow Submarine, which he selected as part of the Indelible Images program in 1997. Introduced Hayao Miyazaki before Spirited Away in 2002. Presented Irving M. Levin Award to George Lucas at 50th SFIFF in 2007. Also participated in Q&A session following the screening of Fog City Mavericks at the Castro Theatre, April 29, 2007.

1997

2002

2007

Comments: West Coast editor, Show magazine, to award Show magazine prize for the “actor, writer, directer or producer whose work in a full-length presentaton holds the most promise for future advancement in the film medium.” which went to director Rangel Vulchanov of Sun and Shadow.

1962

Comments: Subject of a tribute in 1969. Attended screening of Hearts of the West in 1975. Attended Opening Night screening of Swann in Love in 1984. Recipient of the 2004 Lifetime Achievement in Directing Award.

1969

1975

1984

2004, Taking Off, Director

2004, The Firemen’s Ball, Director

2004, Hair, Director

Comments: Attended the Peter J. Owens Award gala for Annette Bening at the 40th San Francisco International in 1997. Attended the following year as the recipient of the Peter J. Owens Award.

1997

1998, Birdy, Actor

Comments: Filled in for Joel McCrea when he no-showed for his tribute. Board of Directors member for the festival. Interviewed Robert Mitchum on stage at Mitchum’s tribute.

1983, Pursued, Screenwriter

Comments: Attended the Peter J. Owens Award gala for Annette Bening at the 40th San Francisco International in 1997. Attended the same event the following year, when her then-husband, Nicolas Cage, was honored.

1997

1998

Comments: Clipson’s films were featured in the performance by the band Tarantel at the live music event Halou, Tarantel and the GreenWorld, held at Mighty, May 9, 2007.

2007, WATERCOLOR NIGHT MONTAGE NO. 7, Director

Comments: Emcee for Opening Night in 1984. Attended Opening Night in 1992. Participated in On the Road at 50 event, honoring Jack Kerouac’s book, in 2007. Also appeared at the screening of Fog City Mavericks at the Castro Theatre, April 29, 2007.

1984

1994, Kika, Actor

1997

2002

2007, Fog City Mavericks, Narrator

1992

Comments: As Advisory Board member for the festival, attended Opening Night events in 1985, and has attended several other Opening Nights. Chose Pather Panchali for Indelible Images in 1997. In 2006, attended onstage interview of Peter J. Owens Award recipient Ed Harris. Appeared at the screening of Fog City Mavericks at the Castro Theatre, April 29, 2007.

2007

1985

1986

1992

1996

1997

2006

Comments: Attended Opening Night in 1975, 1976, 1978 and 1979. Creator of TV show The Streets of San Francisco, he was a generous financial contributor to the Festival and was acknowledged on stage in 1976.

1976

1978

1975

1979

Comments: In 2007, the filmmaker appeared for an evening titled Carved Out of Pavement: The Work of Rob Nilsson. The director screened excerpts from his work and discussed his technique with the audience. He also appeared onstage briefly at the screening of Fog City Mavericks at the Castro Theatre, April 29, 2007.

1984, Signal 7, Director

1986

1988

1996, Chalk, Director

2007

Comments: Appeared at John Frankenheimer retrospective, as the star of Frankenheimer\'s just-finished new feature (which turned out to be Seconds).

1965

Comments: Alloy Orchestra member. Musician for Dans la Nuit, 2004. Blackmail, 2005. Not So Quiet Silents shorts program and The Eagle, 2006.

2004

2005

2006

Comments: Part of the “Russian delegation”; appeared with his documentary The Great Patriotic War.

1965, The Great Patriotic War, Director

Comments: Received the inaugural Midnight Award to honor a dynamic young American actress who has made outstanding contributions to independent and Hollywood cinema. She and fellow honoree Sam Rockwell received the award at a ceremony at the W Hotel, April 28, 2007.

2007

Comments: Author of book on which the film is based; autographed book at screening.

1999, My Father's Dragon

Comments: Appeared at John Frankenheimer tribute, as a star of Frankenheimer\'s just-finished new feature (which turned ut to be Seconds).

1965

Comments: Received the inaugural Midnight Award to honor a dynamic young American actor who has made outstanding contributions to independent and Hollywood cinema. She and fellow honoree Rosario Dawson received the award at a ceremony at the W Hotel, April 28, 2007.

2007

Comments: In 2004, attended as the adult advisor to the youth film Four Short Films About Love.

1996, Zimbabwe Wheel, Director

2004

Comments: Film Society Awards Night presenter in 2006. Appeared at the screening of Fog City Mavericks and participated in a Q&A session at the Castro Theatre, April 29, 2007.

2006

2007, Fog City Mavericks, Documentary Subject

Comments: Performed music from the film at the Castro Theatre with Joe Delia.

1995, The Addiction

Comments: Accepted Akira Kurosawa Award for Lifetime Achievement in Directing on behalf of Satyajit Ray at a screening of The World of Apu on May 4, 1992. Ray had passed away on April 23, 1992, the day before the Festival started.

1992, The World of Apu, Actress

Comments: Attended Opening Night in 1960. Member of Festival board of directors in 1965. Introduced The Bluebird in 1965. Quit board in 1966 in protest over screening of Night Games.

1960

1965

Comments: President of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences Sid Ganis presented Wernor Herzog with the Directing Award at FSAN.

2006

Comments: Attended world premiere screening of She\'s Gotta Have It at the Palace of Fine Arts. When the Marina district suffered a blackout, Lee rose to the stage and entertained the crowd until the power came back on and his film could continue. Crooklyn closed the 1994 Festival. In 2007, Lee received the Film Society Directing Award.

1986, She’s Gotta Have It, Director

1994, Crooklyn, Director

2007, When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts, Director

Comments: Attended Closing Night 1959. He was in The Sound and the Fury (1959), a Jerry Wald-produced film. In attendance at Opening Night 1966. San Francisco native.

1959

1966

Comments: Tennessee Ernie Ford was the 1963 Master of Ceremonies for the Awards Ball November 12.

1963

Comments: Appeared at the Music and Multimedia conference at the Castro Theatre, May 7.

1994

Comments: Appeared at the Music and Multimedia conference at the Castro Theatre, May 7.

1994

Comments: Producer of A Scanner Darkly showed first reel and talked about film.

2006

Comments: Did a reading of Alan Bennett writings for Bennett tribute that he could not attend.

1997

Comments: Appeared as part of the New Director series.

1965, Deathwatch, Director

Comments: Opening Night emcee and introduced films Once There Was a War and Claude in 1967. Opening Night emcee in 1969.

1967

1969

Comments: Attended the Opening Night events in 1981. Subject of a tribute in 1985.

1981

1985, Champagne for Caesar, Actor

1985, The Tomb of Ligeia, Actor

1985, Dragonwyck, Actor

1985, Theatre of Blood, Actor

Comments: Attended with her father, legendary Hong Kong producer Run Run Shaw, for the screening of Enchanting Shadow.

1960

Comments: Native Son Award recipent in 1965. The same year his film Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs was shown at the festival.

1965, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, Producer

Comments: Chose Diary of a Country Priest for Indelible Images in 1997. Appeared at the screening of Fog City Mavericks at the Castro Theatre, April 29, 2007.

1997

2007, Fog City Mavericks, Subject

2007, Murch, Subject

Comments: Walter Shenson was a former San Franciscan and brother-in-law to SFIFF founder, Irving Levin.

1959, The Mouse That Roared, Producer

1999, A Hard Day’s Night, Producer

Comments: Shown as part of program titled Enraptured Images: New Films by Gunvor Nelson and Warren Sonbert.

1990, Natural Features, Director

Comments: The Chamber of Commerce president presented the Native Son Award to Walt Disney at the 1965 festival.

Comments: The actor was honored in the Craft of Cinema retrospective programs during the 1967 festival.

1967

Comments: Widow of Alexander Dovzhenko, subject of a retrospective. She directed several films based on his scenarios.

1969

Comments: Attended reception for Nude in a White Car with wife Simone Signoret in 1959. Subject of a tribute in 1978.

1959

1978, The Roads to the South, Actor

1978, The Wages of Fear, Actor
